page.title: 17BARTESTREE CONVENT
page.content: Originally established in France and called "Our Lady of Refuge," the convent was rehoused at Bartestree, in a building designed by a Mr. Phillipps, in 1863, nearly 122 years ago. It was built then as a Benedictine monastry, which housed 40-50 people until the war. The main function was to care for those aged 12-30, particularly children, who did not go to school, but were taught by the nuns. Then, because of financial problems, a laundry was built to serve the whole area. In 1974, the convent was made a self-sufficient, semi-enclosed one. There are now 12 sisters, and the convent, used for a while as a teenager's home, is now a{home for old {people.
